title: Recreations of Christopher North, Volume 2
author: Wilson, John
snippet: About an hour ago did we, standingon the very beautiful bridge of Perth, see that identical salmon, withhis back-fin just visible above the translucent tide, arrowing up theTay, bold as a bridegroom, and nothing doubting that he should spend hishoneymoon among the gravel-beds of Kinnaird or Moulinearn, or the rockysofas of the Tummel, or the green marble couches of the Tilt.

title: Recreations of Christopher North, Volume 2

title: The recreations of Christopher North
author: Wilson, John
snippet: ing that he should spend his honeymoon among the gravel beds of Kinnaird or Moulenearn, or the rocky sofas of the Tummel, or the green marble couches of the Tilt.

title: The hills of home,
author: Watt, Lauchlan McLean.
snippet: How often and willingly do I not look again in fancy on Tummel, or Manor, or the talking Airdle, or Dee swirling in its Lynn; on the bright burn of Kinnaird, or the golden burn that pours and sulks in the den behind Kingussie! I think shame to leave out one of these enchantresses, but the list would grow too long if I remembered  all; only I may not forget Allan Water, nor birch-wetting Rogie, nor yet Almond; nor, for all its pollutions, that Water of Leithofthe many and well-named mills — Bell's Mills, and Canon Mills, and Silver Mills; nor Redford Burn of pleasant memories;  nor yet, for all its smallness, that

title: Across the plains with other memories and essays,
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: This was a little, lean, and fiery man, with the eyes of a dog and the face of a gipsy; whom I found one morning encamped with his wife and children and his grinder's wheel, beside the burn of Kinnaird.

title: Across the plains,
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis

title: Hospitable England in the seventies;
author: Dana, Richard Henry
snippet: Friends call them Spencer, Kinnaird, Sir John, etc.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: He had left the society before I joined it; but Kinnaird, an able man and an excellent speaker, continued to attend occasionally ; and Brougham, Horner, Jeffrey, James Moncreiff, and other powerful persons, attended regularly, and took an active part in the business, throughout all the three years during which I was an ordinary member.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: James Bruce of Kinnaird died 27th April 1794.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: The party left shortly afternine o'clock, by train, for Larbert, where they visited thechurchyard, in which lies the body of Bruce, the AbyssinanTraveller, born in 1730, who died from an accident at his owndoor at Kinnaird, helping a lady into her carriage, 1794, andthence drove to Tor wood.
